title.narrative: PITCH Regional Programmes (Eastern Europe & Central Asia)

description.narrative: 1. City administration signed on to the Paris Declaration (and joined the Zero TB Cities Initiative, if the scope of work permits), including commitment and action plan to achieve 90-90-90 targets, particularly among the key populations. 2. Key populations included as priority groups and partners/service providers in the municipal plans; and the progress on key populations’ related targets tracked. 3. Increased city funding and endorsed HIV (and TB, if the scope of work permits) city improvement plan/s to strengthen response among the key populations. 4. Strengthened partnership between municipal government and NGOs, including key populations representatives on relevant city coordination group/s. 5. Strengthened advocacy capacity among representatives of the key populations communities, particularly new leaders, to effectively collaborate with municipal government, across the key populations groups, as well as with public health, human rights and other organisations relevant to the HIV/AIDS (and, where feasible, TB) response.

AFEW International and partners EVA, St. Petersburg and AFEW Kyrgyzstan, Bishkek; co–created a project strengthening civil society (CS) engagement with receptive public officials (city administration, politicians, health, law enforcement, finance). The project builds CS advocacy and influencing skills to engage with existing decision-makers and enlarge this pool of supporters at municipal level, contributing to strengthened political commitment and endorsement of international protocols on Key Population (KP) HIV services/budgeting. There is a cross-cutting focus on adolescent girls and young women (AGYW) as a priority group impacted by specific HIV drivers. The project leverages increasing responsibility at municipal level leading on HIV and health initiatives, balancing community activism with nuanced diplomacy to effect change.
With the proposed activities, IFRC and Red Cross Red Crescent National Societies of the CIS will engage civil society organizations and representatives of key populations to create a common platform for a professional dialogue with CIS parliamentarians, the Eurasian Economic Union, the Secretariat of the CIS, state health institutions, academic communities, as well as mass media with the aim to develop and adopt model legislation, creating friendly environment for people living with HIV (PLWHIV), reducing stigma and discrimination, and ensuring better access to HIV-related services.

The proposed programme will contribute to strengthening political support among municipal level governments for effective HIV/AIDS response among the key populations in two cities in the Russian Federation and EECA region affected by HIV/AIDS, and should cater to two or more of the key populations: LGBTI, people who use drugs, and sex workers, including adolescent girls and young women. This will contribute to cities in the Russian Federation and EECA region joining the fast-track city initiative and building political support for an HIV/AIDS response focused on key populations.

description.narrative: Regional Programmes AFEW 2020-1 disbursement

For this outcome Stigma refers to both the internal stigma (self-stigma) experienced and expressed by KPs and AGYW themselves, as well as external stigma and discrimination expressed by decision makers and those with widespread influence (government, media etc) as well as communities, religious and traditional leaders, service providers, families etc toward KPs and AGYW. This outcome focuses on achieving changes in the beliefs, attitudes and behaviour of those who express this external stigma and discrimination, in the hope that KPs and AGYW experience less stigma and discrimination because of their HIV status and/or gender and sexuality over the course of PITCH. Our assumption is that as levels of external stigma reduce, incidences of self-stigma also reduce, contributing to an increase in public demand for access to HIV-related services for KPs and AGYW.

title.narrative: IndS1.1 (EECA): Decision makers/implementers demonstrate changed attitude towards KPs and AGYW on an issue or claim

description.narrative: IndS1.1 (EECA): Decision makers/implementers demonstrate changed attitude towards KPs and AGYW on an issue or claim

title.narrative: S3: Enhanced capacity to capture evidence

description.narrative: This outcome focuses on demonstrating increased capacity among PITCH partners to collect and use evidence (e.g. through reviews of reports and other public documents, research using interviews and surveys, capturing data through monitoring activities etc) to inform their advocacy. It is important that the focus of partners' reporting is on explaining in what ways their capacity to document evidence has improved, and what they have done with this evidence. This should be described and analysed by partners from the perspective of planning and implementing their advocacy. Where partners feel that their evidence-based advocacy has contributed toward a change in policy, when reporting against the indicators below, please provide evidence that illustrates how your advocacy contributed to this policy change.

title.narrative: IndS3.1: # of country partners with improved capacity to capture evidence aligned to their advocacy work

description.narrative: IndS3.1: # of country partners with improved capacity to capture evidence aligned to their advocacy work

title.narrative: IndS3.2: # of new evidence produced or existing evidence synthesised by country partners to inform their advocacy efforts

description.narrative: IndS3.2: # of new evidence produced or existing evidence synthesised by country partners to inform their advocacy efforts

This outcome focuses on demonstrating the changing capacities of PITCH partners to influence the advocacy agenda in their countries in relation to the specific advocacy asks and rights of KPs and AGYW. The ability to influence and â€˜set' advocacy agendas is based on the ability to develop evidence-based, strategic and targeted advocacy plans and activities that include clear recommendations for decision makers and other advocacy targets.

title.narrative: IndS2.1 (EECA): Extent which country partners utilize advocacy opportunities to share policy positions and strategies with relevant stakeholders

description.narrative: IndS2.1 (EECA): Extent which country partners utilize advocacy opportunities to share policy positions and strategies with relevant stakeholders

title.narrative: IndS2.2: # of country partners with evidence based advocacy strategy or plan with clear policy targets and recommendations

description.narrative: IndS2.2: # of country partners with evidence based advocacy strategy or plan with clear policy targets and recommendations

This outcome focuses on the experiences of PITCH partners when engaging advocacy targets that can influence decision-making processes. These advocacy targets will be global, regional, national, or local government representatives and politicians, as well as religious and traditional leaders and the police etc. We are looking for evidence of these advocacy targets listening to local and national civil society, including youth and KP-led organisations. We are also looking for evidence of these advocacy targets amending or introducing new policies and encouraging practice and behaviour that responds to the needs and rights of KPs and AGYW. Moreover, we are looking to draw connections between the increased capacity of PITCH partners and the effective engagement of these advocacy targets.

title.narrative: L1: With critical mass of support, civil society holds governments to account, uses evidence from constituencies, shapes an effective funded national HIV response, and reduces barriers to services

description.narrative: This outcome is concerned with achieving a long-term increase in the influence of civil society over government policy and funding of the national HIV response and, fundamentally, a reduction in barriers faced by Key Populations and AGYW to accessing services. Through this outcome PITCH will seek to achieve increased political commitment for HIV and SRHR services that target KPs and AGYW, and to develop the capacity of PITCH country partners to hold governments to account for the implementation of policies and other political commitments at all levels. With this outcome we hope to achieve a more informed and organised movement of community-led CSOs (KPs and AGYW) working together and engaging decision/opinion/policy makers, health care providers, religious leaders etc towards improving HIV and SRHR services (including implementation â€“ funding, decriminalization, promoting harm reduction) for KPs and AGYW.

title.narrative: IndL1.1 (EECA): Level of political commitment for HIV and SRHR services targeting KPs and AGYW

description.narrative: IndL1.1 (EECA): Level of political commitment for HIV and SRHR services targeting KPs and AGYW

title.narrative: IndL1.2 (EECA): # of country partners with improved capacity to hold their governments accountable for the implementation of national (such as reform agenda), global and regional commitments

description.narrative: IndL1.2 (EECA): # of country partners with improved capacity to hold their governments accountable for the implementation of national (such as reform agenda), global and regional commitments

This outcome is designed to track the progress of PITCH partners in increasing their level of interaction with national level CSOs; social justice networks; local, district and national level authorities; and international organisations including AU, UNAIDS, Global Fund, and WHO. We are looking to better understand how PITCH is having an impact on the ability of partners to confidently engage in dialogue and collaborate with a range of stakeholders that have an influence over changes in policy and practice in relations to meeting the needs of KPS and AGYW. Changes in the levels of interaction are measured through the number of meetings etc between implementing partners and the stakeholders referred to here where advocacy is carried out. Through this outcome we also seek to understand changes in the level of capacity and confidence to advocate with country, regional and global level advocacy targets, and the impact this has on changes in levels of engagement between PITCH partners and these same stakeholders.

title.narrative: IndS4.1 (EECA): # of meetings/foras/symposiums with decision makers in which country partners represent themselves and share their positions/advocacy asks at country, regional and global level.

description.narrative: IndS4.1 (EECA): # of meetings/foras/symposiums with decision makers in which country partners represent themselves and share their positions/advocacy asks at country, regional and global level.

title.narrative: M4: Dutch MoFA, DFID and other change champions jointly utilise evidence and real-time intelligence to influence global policy and funding

description.narrative: This outcome relates to the work of influential international stakeholders such as the Dutch MoFA and DFID, and the need for community, local and national level perspectives, experiences, and evidence to inform the work of these international stakeholders. PITCH seeks to help increase and improve the flow of information and evidence from the global to the local levels, and from the local to the global levels. This will help to shape thinking and approaches for a stronger advocacy and policy impact.

title.narrative: IndM4.2 (EECA): Number of change champions who provide political supports to PITCH priorities by bringing them to regional or global political platforms (side events, UN boards, resolutionsâ€¦)
